Knowledge Point: Ulwa makes frequent use of a class of what are termed here “subject markers”. These are a set of postnominal determiners that occur in subject \isi{noun phrase}s. Though never obligatory, they are very common. When present, they always occur as the final element of their NP. The three basic subject markers have the same form as, and are clearly related to, the third \isi{person} subject \isi{pronoun}s described in \sectref{sec:6.1}. The subject markers are given in \REF{ex:det:1}.\footnote{The 3\textsc{sg} subject-marker \is{subject marker} form /mï/ is glossed as ‘3\textsc{sg.subj}’, since it is formally distinct from the 3\textsc{sg} \isi{object-marker} form /ma=/, which is glossed as ‘3\textsc{sg.obj’}.}
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The \isi{subject marker} can occur with either \isi{animate} or \isi{inanimate} referents, as seen in examples \REF{ex:det:2} through \REF{ex:det:7}. In these examples, each NP marked by a \isi{subject marker} is translated with the \ili{English} definite article ‘the’. This reflects the fact that subject markers (as determiners) may function to signal \isi{definiteness} (or \isi{specificity}) in a referent. That said, it is often possible to translate NPs with subject markers with the \ili{English} \isi{indefinite} article ‘a, an’ or with no article at all. Indeed, the \isi{semantic} range and discourse functions of these articles remain largely unknown to me.
Content 1: \gsrc Mana \textbf{mï} liyu. | \gll mana \textbf{mï} li-u | \gls spear 3SG.SUBJ down-put | \glt `The spear fell.’
Content 2: \gsrc Tïn \textbf{min} mo maka lamndu kon anmbas. | \gll tïn \textbf{min} ma=u maka lamndu ko=n an-mbï-asa | \gls dog 3DU 3SG.OBJ=from thus pig INDF=OBL out-here-hit | \glt `The two dogs thus chased a pig out from there.’

Knowledge Point: These examples illustrate how subject markers can indicate whether a \isi{common noun} subject is \isi{singular}, as in \REF{ex:det:2}, \REF{ex:det:3}, and \REF{ex:det:4}; \isi{plural}, as in \REF{ex:det:5} and \REF{ex:det:6}; or \isi{dual}, as in \REF{ex:det:7}. Subject markers can also be used with \isi{proper noun}s, as in \REF{ex:det:8} and \REF{ex:det:9}.

Content 2: \gsrc Wot yana \textbf{mï} lïmndï mala. | \gll wot yana \textbf{mï} lïmndï ma=ala | \gls younger woman 3SG.SUBJ eye 3SG.OBJ=see | \glt `The younger sister saw her.’
Content 3: \gsrc Sokoy \textbf{mï} ango anmap tembi. | \gll sokoy \textbf{mï} ango anma=p tembi | \gls tobacco 3SG.SUBJ NEG good=COP bad | \glt `The tobacco isn’t good; [it’s] bad.’

Content 5: \gsrc Alum \textbf{ndï} se. | \gll alum \textbf{ndï} sa-e | \gls child 3PL cry-IPFV | \glt `The children were crying.’

Knowledge Point: Subject markers can also be used with recent \isi{loanword}s, as in \REF{ex:det:10}, which contains the \ili{Tok Pisin} word polis ‘police’.
Content 1: \gsrc Polis \textbf{ndï} ndiya ata ma keka namndu ndïwalinda. | \gll polis \textbf{ndï} ndï=iya ata ma keka namndu ndï=wali-nda | \gls police 3PL 3PL=toward up go completely pig 3PL=hit-IRR | \glt `The police will go up to them and completely kill the pigs.’

Knowledge Point: Throughout the examples in this grammar, subject markers are glossed with a ‘3’ (for third \isi{person}).\footnote{This is done for two reasons: first, the forms of the subject markers are identical to those of the third \isi{person} \isi{personal pronoun}s; second, subject markers can only appear with third \isi{person} \isi{noun phrase}s. They never occur with first \isi{person} or second \isi{person} \isi{noun phrase}s. Thus, they do indeed index the third \isi{person}.} Subject markers never appear with \isi{personal pronoun}s.\footnote{Thus, the following sequences are ungrammatical: *nï mï, *ngunan min, *min min, *un ndï, *ndï ndï, and so on. However, subject markers may follow certain other pronominal forms, such as \is{indefinite pronoun} indefinite or \isi{interrogative pronoun}s, although some usages may be only marginally acceptable (see \sectref{sec:6.4} and \sectref{sec:6.5}).} Although apparently not obligatory, subject markers can be useful for clarifying meaning in certain circumstances. First, since \isi{adjective}s (as well as \isi{possessive pronoun}s) may be used substantively, the presence of a \isi{subject marker} may clarify that an \isi{adjective} or other modifier is functioning as the subject of the sentence, as in \REF{ex:det:11} and \REF{ex:det:12}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ambi mï} keka mat nin ndïl. | \gll \textbf{ambi} \textbf{mï} keka ma=tï nin ndï=lï | \gls big 3SG.SUBJ completely 3SG.OBJ=take thorn 3PL=put | \glt `The big one [= a pig] completely got him and put [him] on thorns.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Nïnji ndï} anma iye. | \gll \textbf{nï-nji} \textbf{ndï} anma i-e | \gls 1SG-POSS 3PL good go.PFV-DEP | \glt `My [comrades] came [home] well.’

Knowledge Point: Also, in \is{equative predication} equative or \is{attributive predication} attributive sentences that lack any overt verb form (i.e., sentences that contain no overt \isi{copula}, \sectref{sec:10.1}), the \isi{subject marker} helps to break the clause into two halves: everything up to and including the \isi{subject marker} is clearly the subject of the clause; everything following must be the \isi{predicate}, as illustrated by sentences \REF{ex:det:13} through \REF{ex:det:16}, in which square brackets enclose first the [subject] and then the [\isi{predicate}].
Content 1: \gsrc Ulum \textbf{ndï} ndïnji alo. | \gll {[ulum} {\textbf{ndï}]} {[ndï-nji} ala {wo]} | \gls {[palm} {3PL]} {[3PL-POSS} PL.DIST {own]} | \glt ‘The sago palms are their very own.’
Content 2: \gsrc Supam Sinanam \textbf{min} atana wot. | \gll {[Supam} Sinanam {\textbf{min}]} {[atana} {wot]} | \gls {[[name]} {[name]} {3DU]} {[older.sister} {younger]} | \glt `Supam and Sinanam were sisters.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:det:16} further illustrates how \isi{coordinate}d subjects that lack any overt \isi{coordinator} (\sectref{sec:12.1}) may be clarified as such by means of the \isi{subject marker}. The \isi{subject marker} is all the more valuable in this regard when one or more of the members of the conjoined subject is left unexpressed. In example \REF{ex:det:17}, the \isi{dual} marker indicates that there are two subjects, even though only one is expressed.
Content 1: \gsrc Supam Sinanam \textbf{min} atana wot. | \gll {[Supam} Sinanam {\textbf{min}]} {[atana} {wot]} | \gls {[[name]} {[name]} {3DU]} {[older.sister} {younger]} | \glt `Supam and Sinanam were sisters.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Carobim min} wa mape. | \gll \textbf{Carobim} \textbf{min} wa ma=p-e | \gls [name] 3DU village 3SG.OBJ=be{-ipfv} | \glt `Carobim and he [= Danny] were in the village.’

Knowledge Point: Thus, in addition to serving as an indicator of \isi{number}, the \isi{subject marker} can function as an \isi{associative plural} marker (or \isi{associative dual} marker) -- that is, when following a noun, a \isi{subject marker} can be used to give the interpretation of “that noun plus others associated with it”. In this way, the \isi{dual} \isi{subject marker} indexes that exactly one associated referent is to be understood, whereas the \isi{plural} \isi{subject marker} indexes that two or more additional referents are to be understood. This \isi{associative plural} function of subject markers (or \isi{object marker}s) is most commonly used with \isi{personal noun}s. An example with a \isi{plural} \isi{subject marker} is given in \REF{ex:det:18}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Dorothy ndï} molop. | \gll \textbf{Dorothy} \textbf{ndï} ma=lo-p | \gls [name] 3PL 3SG.OBJ=go-PFV | \glt `Dorothy and the others went there.’

Knowledge Point: An example of an \isi{object marker} (\sectref{sec:7.3}) functioning as an \isi{associative plural} marker is given in \REF{ex:det:19}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Otto} \textbf{ndïkïna}. | \gll \textbf{Otto} \textbf{ndï}=kï-na | \gls [name] 3PL=say-IRR | \glt `[We] will tell Otto and the others.’

Knowledge Point: In other circumstances, the \isi{subject marker} can help prevent a subject from being misinterpreted as being an object or \isi{oblique}. Since it is common for subjects to be omitted, the absence of a \isi{subject marker} could lead to such a miscue. The elicited sentence \REF{ex:det:20} is ambiguous, since yeta nungol ‘boys’ could be interpreted either as the subject (without a \isi{subject marker}) or as the object (with a \isi{pro-drop}ped subject); in sentence \REF{ex:det:21}, on the other hand, the subject is clearly defined because it contains the \isi{subject marker}.
Content 1: \gsrc Yeta nungol ndïnap le. | \gll yeta nungol ndï=nap lo-e | \gls man child 3PL=for go-IPFV | \glt (a) ‘The boys would go around on account of them [the girls].’\\’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Yeta nungol ndï} ndïnap le. | \gll \textbf{yeta} \textbf{nungol} \textbf{ndï} ndï=nap lo-e | \gls man child 3PL 3PL=for go-IPFV | \glt `The boys would go around on account of them [= the girls].’

Knowledge Point: Likewise the subject of sentence \REF{ex:det:22} is clear because it contains the \isi{subject marker}. The subject of the elicited sentence \REF{ex:det:23}, however, is ambiguous.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Inom mï} manji ay mamap. | \gll \textbf{inom} \textbf{mï} ma-nji ay ma=ama-p | \gls mother 3SG.SUBJ 3SG.OBJ-POSS sago 3SG.OBJ=eat-PFV | \glt `Mother ate her sago.’
Content 2: \gsrc Inom manji ay mamap. | \gll inom ma-nji ay ma=ama-p | \gls mother 3SG.OBJ-POSS sago 3SG.OBJ=eat-PFV | \glt (a) ‘Mother ate her sago.’\\’

Knowledge Point: A similar situation can also be seen in the pair of sentences \REF{ex:det:24} and \REF{ex:det:25}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Nungol mï} ndala aw ndïnep. | \gll \textbf{nungol} \textbf{mï} ndï=ala aw ndï=ne-p | \gls child 3SG.SUBJ 3PL=for betel.nut 3PL=harvest-PFV | \glt `The child harvested betel nut for them.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nungol ndala aw ndïnep. | \gll nungol ndï=ala aw ndï=ne-p | \gls child 3PL=for betel.nut 3PL=harvest-PFV | \glt (a) ‘The child harvested betel nut for them.’\\’

Knowledge Point: Although subject markers are used with great frequency and may be useful for marking \isi{number} or clarifying the subject in ambiguous circumstances, they do not occur in every subject NP. Their absence may be a simple omission (the product of casual speech), or it may rather be that their use is optional. Often, no difference in meaning can be detected between when subject markers are present and when they are absent. That said, there do seem to be some patterns underlying their absence. For example, subject markers seem more likely to be omitted when the subject is a \isi{proper noun}, as in examples \REF{ex:det:23bis} through \REF{ex:det:26}.
Content 1: \gsrc Alkumot yana minkotïp. | \gll Alkumot yana Ø min=kot-p | \gls [name] woman (3SG.SUBJ) 3DU=break-PFV | \glt `The woman Alkumot bore them.’
Content 2: \gsrc Elias tïnanga. | \gll Elias Ø tïnanga | \gls [name] (3SG.SUBJ) arise | \glt `Elias got up.’

Knowledge Point: Subject markers are perhaps also more likely to be omitted when the verb is \isi{intransitive}. This is perhaps unsurprising, since the role of the single core NP (i.e., subject) is easily determined by default in an \isi{intransitive} clause without needing any special marking. In other words, Ulwa appears to exhibit \isi{differential subject marking} in this regard. Subject markers may also be omitted more frequently when the referent of the subject is less definite, although I have not found any strict rules for their omission. In sentences \REF{ex:det:27} and \REF{ex:det:28}, the subjects are \isi{indefinite}. The subject NPs do not have subject markers.
Content 1: \gsrc Lamndu keka ndamap ulwap. | \gll lamndu Ø keka ndï=ama-p ulwa=p | \gls pig (3SG.SUBJ) completely 3PL=eat-PFV nothing=COP | \glt `A pig completely ate them.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ankam ulwap. | \gll ankam Ø ulwa=p | \gls person (3PL) nothing=COP | \glt `No one is left.’

Knowledge Point: It may be noteworthy that it is common not to include \isi{object marker}s in \is{existential predication} \isi{negative} existential constructions, such as in \REF{ex:det:28}. This may suggest something of the definiteness-indexing nature of these markers. However, although rare, there are examples of subject markers being used in such \isi{negative} existential constructions \REF{ex:det:29}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ankam ulwap. | \gll ankam Ø ulwa=p | \gls person (3PL) nothing=COP | \glt `No one is left.’
Content 2: \gsrc Kumba mo iye na \textbf{ndï} nap. | \gll Kumba ma=u i-e na \textbf{ndï} ulwa na-p | \gls Bun 3SG.OBJ=from go.PFV-DEP talk 3PL nothing DETR-be | \glt `There are no [more] stories about [me] coming from Bun [village].’

Knowledge Point: Like the set of \isi{subject marker}s, the set of “object markers” consists of postnominal determiners that occur as the final element in their respective NPs. The forms of the object markers are identical to the forms in the set of third-\isi{singular} objective \isi{personal pronoun}s (\sectref{sec:6.1}) -- thus, they are mostly identical to the set of \isi{subject marker}s. The main exception, however, is found in the \textsc{3sg} forms, which differ between the subject and object paradigms. Also, in certain \isi{phonological} environments, the \textsc{3du} forms are likewise distinct. The object markers \mbox{are given in \REF{ex:det:30}.}
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Object markers may follow either \is{common noun} common or \isi{proper noun}s, and they may have either \isi{animate} or \isi{inanimate} referents. The object markers -- whether 3\textsc{sg} \REF{ex:det:31}, 3\textsc{du} \REF{ex:det:32}, or 3\textsc{pl} \REF{ex:det:33} -- \isi{clitic}ize to the following verb.

Content 2: \gsrc Inom mï utam \textbf{minwanap}. | \gll inom mï utam \textbf{min}=wana-p | \gls mother 3SG.SUBJ yam 3DU=cook-PFV | \glt `Mother cooked two yams.’

Content 1: \gsrc Inom mï utam \textbf{nduwanap}. | \gll inom mï utam \textbf{ndï=}wana-p | \gls mother 3SG.SUBJ yam 3PL=cook-PFV | \glt `Mother cooked the yams.’
Content 2: \gsrc Tïn ndï lamndu \textbf{masap}. | \gll tïn ndï lamndu \textbf{ma}=asa-p | \gls dog 3PL pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `The dogs killed the pig.’

Content 4: \gsrc Tïn ndï lamndu \textbf{minasap}. | \gll tïn ndï lamndu \textbf{min}=asa-p | \gls dog 3PL pig 3DU=hit-PFV | \glt `The dogs killed two pigs.’

No similar \isi{allomorphy} occurs with \textsc{3du} \REF{ex:det:38} or \textsc{3pl} \REF{ex:det:39} object markers when in the same environment.

Knowledge Point: Object markers may occur with verbs marked for any \isi{TAM} category, and there are no distinctions in the markers based on such \isi{TAM} distinctions. Thus they occur in \isi{imperfective} \REF{ex:det:40}, \isi{perfective} \REF{ex:det:41}, and \isi{irrealis} \REF{ex:det:42} \isi{verb phrase}s. Any \isi{transitive} verb can be preceded by one of these \isi{object-marking} \isi{proclitic}s.
Content 1: \gsrc Tïn mï mïnda \textbf{mame}. | \gll tïn mï mïnda \textbf{ma}=ama-e | \gls dog 3SG.SUBJ banana 3SG.OBJ=eat-IPFV | \glt `The dog is eating the banana.’
Content 2: \gsrc Tïn mï mïnda \textbf{mamap}. | \gll tïn mï mïnda \textbf{ma}=ama-p | \gls dog 3SG.SUBJ banana 3SG.OBJ=eat-PFV | \glt `The dog ate the banana.’

Knowledge Point: Although it may be possible to explain the \isi{allomorph} [mo=] (for ma= ‘3\textsc{sg.obj’)} in terms of simple \isi{phonological} conditioning (that is, without considering \isi{morphology}, \sectref{sec:2.5.7}), the form mini= ‘3\textsc{du.obj’} is clearly a \isi{morphological}ly conditioned change, since, elsewhere, consecutive \isi{consonant}s are simply \isi{degeminate}d. Thus, one should expect the \isi{allomorph}, were it \isi{phonological}ly conditioned, to be \textsuperscript{†}[mi=]. Indeed, the form mini= ‘3\textsc{du.obj’} only appears before verbs, not even before \isi{postposition}s, suggesting that \isi{object-marker} \isi{clitic}s for verbs are somewhat more closely affiliated with their hosts than are \isi{object-marker} \isi{clitic}s for \isi{postposition}s.} The \isi{allomorph} mini= ‘3\textsc{du.obj’} can thus be observed when the morpheme immediately precedes an initial /n/ of a \isi{verb stem} \REF{ex:det:43}, but not when it precedes other \isi{consonant}s (e.g., /l/) \REF{ex:det:44}.

Knowledge Point: Although helpful in designating the \isi{number} of referents in an object NP, object markers, like \isi{subject marker}s (\sectref{sec:7.1}), are not always included in their respective NPs. Again, their absence may be a simple omission, the product of casual speech. Their omission does, however, seem to be more likely when the referent is less definite, but no clear correlation has been found in the corpus. In other words, Ulwa may exhibit a form of \is{object marking} \isi{differential object marking} in addition to exhibiting \isi{differential subject marking} (\sectref{sec:7.1}). The objects of examples \REF{ex:det:48} and \REF{ex:det:49} are both \isi{indefinite}; in \REF{ex:det:48} the object receives the \isi{object marker} (for each of two verbs), whereas in \REF{ex:det:49} it does not.

Content 2: \gsrc Ndï tïmbïl itap. | \gll ndï tïmbïl ita-p | \gls 3PL fence build-PFV | \glt `They built a fence.’

Content 4: \gsrc Ndï tïmbïl itap. | \gll ndï tïmbïl ita-p | \gls 3PL fence build-PFV | \glt `They built a fence.’

Knowledge Point: Another set of examples with \isi{indefinite} object NPs contrasts the absence \REF{ex:det:50} and presence \REF{ex:det:51} of the \isi{object marker}.
Content 1: \gsrc Un ay nïkap? | \gll un ay nïkï-p | \gls 2PL sago dig-PFV | \glt ‘Did you make sago?’
Content 2: \gsrc Imba nape ay \textbf{ndïnkap} \textbf{ndïn} amblan up. | \gll imba na-p-e ay \textbf{ndï}=nïkï-p \textbf{ndï}=n ambla=n u-p | \gls night DETR-be{-dep} sago 3PL=dig-PFV 3PL=OBL PL.REFL=OBL put-PFV | \glt `At night [they] made sago [packets] and left them for themselves.’

Knowledge Point: In addition to appearing as the final element in verbal object NPs (that is, immediately preceding verbs), object markers occur as the final elements of NPs that are the objects of \isi{postposition}s, as in examples \REF{ex:det:52} through \REF{ex:det:56}.
Content 1: \gsrc Kayngam i ya \textbf{maya} atay. | \gll Kayngam i ya \textbf{ma}=iya ata-i | \gls [name] go.PFV coconut 3SG.OBJ=toward up-go.PFV | \glt `Kayngam went, climbed up a coconut tree.’
Content 2: \gsrc An wolka ngata \textbf{ndul} iye. | \gll an wolka ngata \textbf{ndï=}ul i-e | \gls 1PL.EXCL again grand 3PL=with go.PFV-DEP | \glt `We again went with the ancestors.’

Knowledge Point: Object markers are also found in NPs marked with the \isi{oblique marker} =n \textsc{‘obl’}, as in \REF{ex:det:57} and \REF{ex:det:58}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ay \textbf{man} mïnanap. | \gll ay \textbf{ma}=n mï=na-na-p | \gls sago 3SG.OBJ=OBL 3SG.SUBJ=DETR-feed-PFV | \glt `[They] fed him with the sago.’
Content 2: \gsrc An mïnda \textbf{ndïn} malan up ndamap. | \gll an mïnda \textbf{ndï}=n manal u-p ndï=ama-p | \gls 1PL.EXCL banana 3PL=OBL hot.water put-PFV 3PL=eat-PFV | \glt `We boiled bananas and ate them.’\footnote{The speaker \is{metathesis} metathesizes the /n/ and /l/ in manal ‘hot water’

Knowledge Point: In addition to the three object markers used for indexing what are usually definite referents (whether \isi{singular}, \isi{dual}, or \isi{plural}), there is a (third-\isi{singular}) \isi{indefinite} marker, ko= ‘\textsc{indf}’, clearly derived from the \isi{numeral} kwa {\textasciitilde} kwe ‘one’. I consider this form to be a sort of \isi{object marker}, both because it tends to \isi{clitic}ize to the following verb, \isi{postposition}, or \isi{oblique marker} and because it never appears in subject NPs: only the forms /kwa/ or /kwe/ may appear in this position (and when they do they have definite reference, i.e., ‘one’). Given that it is not found with nouns in subject NPs, but is rather thus restricted in use, the \isi{indefinite} marker ko= ‘\textsc{indf}’ is not considered to be an “\isi{indefinite} article”.\footnote{Note, however, that the form [ko] can occur as a free morpheme. When it does, it is to be interpreted as the \isi{modal adverb} ko ‘just’, not as the \isi{indefinite} \isi{object marker} ko= ‘\textsc{indf}’, with which it is probably etymologically related. Perhaps another reason for not considering ko= ‘\textsc{indf}’ to be an article is that it is never obligatory.} The \isi{indefinite} \isi{object marker} is illustrated by examples \REF{ex:det:59} through \REF{ex:det:63}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ala nï nji \textbf{kosap}! | \gll ala nï nji \textbf{ko}=asa-p | \gls PL.DIST 1SG thing INDF=hit-PFV | \glt `Guys, I killed something!’
Content 2: \gsrc Ndï ango wondi \textbf{kotïn}. | \gll ndï ango wondi \textbf{ko}=tï-n | \gls 3PL NEG bandicoot INDF=take-PFV | \glt `They didn’t get a [single] bandicoot.’

Knowledge Point: This marker is commonly used in demands or \isi{request}s to be given something, such as the very common \isi{request} to be passed betel nut \REF{ex:det:64}.
Content 1: \gsrc Aw \textbf{kot} nïnan! | \gll aw \textbf{ko}=tï nï=na-n | \gls betel.nut INDF=take 1SG=give-IMP | \glt `Please pass the betel nut!’

Knowledge Point: Sentence \REF{ex:det:65} likewise illustrates the use of the \isi{indefinite} marker ko= ‘\textsc{indf}’ in a demand to be given something.
Content 1: \gsrc Kaw nungol \textbf{kot} nïnata! | \gll kaw nungol \textbf{ko}=tï nï=na-ta | \gls cow child INDF=take 1SG=give-COND | \glt `Give me a calf!’

Knowledge Point: Although etymologically related to the form kwa ‘one’, the definite numerical sense of ‘one’ is generally not felt in the \isi{object marker}. Rather, to give the sense of ‘(exactly) one’, the \isi{numeral} itself is used, followed by a 3\textsc{sg} marker, as in examples \REF{ex:det:66}, \REF{ex:det:67}, and \REF{ex:det:68}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mï may ndimbam lop \textbf{kwa} \textbf{molop} lïp malep. | \gll mï ma=i ndï=imbam lo-p \textbf{kwa} \textbf{ma}=lo-p lï-p ma=ale-p | \gls 3SG.SUBJ 3SG.OBJ=go.PFV 3PL=under go-PFV one 3SG.OBJ=cut-PFV put-PFV 3SG.OBJ=scrape-PFV | \glt `She went there, went under them, cut one [= a palm] down, and scraped it.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï \textbf{kwa} \textbf{mol} ne | \gll nï \textbf{kwa} \textbf{ma}=ul ni-e | \gls 1SG one 3SG.OBJ=with act-IPFV | \glt `I was making one [= an armband].’
Content 3: \gsrc Nïnji wot yana \textbf{kwa} \textbf{mï} nip. | \gll nï-nji wot yana \textbf{kwa} \textbf{mï} ni-p | \gls 1SG-POSS younger woman one 3SG.SUBJ die-PFV | \glt `One younger sister of mine has died.’

Knowledge Point: Sometimes the only expressed element in an object NP (whether the \isi{direct object} of a \isi{transitive} verb or the object preceding a \isi{postposition} or \isi{oblique marker}) is an \isi{object marker}. Since these are identical in form to third \isi{person} non-subject personal pronominal forms and since first \isi{person} and second \isi{person} \isi{pronoun}s may also occur in these positions, it is probably most parsimonious to view these all as \isi{pronoun}s. That is, when no nominal is expressed in an object NP consisting solely of the form ma= ‘3\textsc{sg.obj}’, min= ‘3\textsc{du}’, or ndï= ‘3\textsc{pl}’, these may be treated simply as object \isi{pronoun}s, as in examples \REF{ex:det:69} through \REF{ex:det:80}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï \textbf{mayte}. | \gll ndï \textbf{ma}=ita-e | \gls 3PL 3SG.OBJ=build-IPFV | \glt `They were building it.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï \textbf{unul} wa mana. | \gll nï \textbf{un}=ul wa ma-na | \gls 1SG 2PL=with village go-IRR | \glt `I will go with you to the village.’

Knowledge Point: In examples \REF{ex:det:81} through \REF{ex:det:86}, \isi{demonstrative} determiners occur as the final elements of subject NPs. They all have spatial \isi{deictic} force, pointing to referents either near or far. They may occur with either \is{common noun} common or \isi{proper noun}s. Although nouns are not marked in any way for \isi{number}, adnominal demonstratives agree with their nouns’ covert \isi{number}: \isi{singular}, \isi{dual}, or \isi{plural}.
Content 1: \gsrc Inom \textbf{nga} mawanape. | \gll inom \textbf{nga} ma=wana-p-e | \gls mother SG.PROX 3SG.OBJ=cook-PFV-DEP | \glt `This woman cooked it.’
Content 2: \gsrc Awngala \textbf{la} kuk ato im andawatawe. | \gll awngala \textbf{ala} kuk ata-u im anda=wat-aw-e | \gls bird.species PL.DIST gather up-from tree SG.DIST=atop-put{-ipfv} | \glt `Those birds are gathering up into that tree.’

Knowledge Point: Demonstratives may function pronominally, as in \REF{ex:det:87} and \REF{ex:det:88},
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Anda} man ute: … | \gll \textbf{anda} ma=n u=ta-e | \gls SG.DIST 3SG.OBJ=OBL 2SG=say-DEP | \glt `That one told you: …’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Andin} wot kokot nangani nalïp. | \gll \textbf{andin} wot ko=kot nï=angani na-lï-p | \gls DU.DIST younger INDF=break 1SG=behind DETR-put-PFV | \glt `Those two [= my parents] bore a younger sibling after me.’

Knowledge Point: As a spatial \isi{deictic} word, nga ‘\textsc{sg.prox}’ (‘this’) can mean ‘here’ \REF{ex:det:89}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Nga} unji ani ngala ata \textbf{ngap}. | \gll \textbf{nga} u-nji ani ngala ata \textbf{nga}=p | \gls SG.PROX 2SG-POSS bilum PL.PROX up SG.PROX=be | \glt `Here, these bilum [= string bags] of yours are up here.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:det:89} also illustrates the common use of \isi{demonstrative} determiners in \is{possession} possessive \isi{phrase}s, further illustrated by examples \REF{ex:det:90} through \REF{ex:det:93}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Nga} unji ani ngala ata \textbf{ngap}. | \gll \textbf{nga} u-nji ani ngala ata \textbf{nga}=p | \gls SG.PROX 2SG-POSS bilum PL.PROX up SG.PROX=be | \glt `Here, these bilum [= string bags] of yours are up here.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Nïnji nungol ngala} mbïpe. | \gll \textbf{nï-nji} nungol \textbf{ngala} mbï-p-e | \gls 1SG-POSS child PL.PROX here-be-IPFV | \glt `My children live here.’
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Manji na ngala} mï ndïtana. | \gll \textbf{ma-nji} na \textbf{ngala} mï ndï=ta-na | \gls 3SG.OBJ-POSS talk PL.PROX 3SG.SUBJ 3PL=say-IRR | \glt `These stories of his -- he will tell them.’

Knowledge Point: Demonstrative determiners occur not only in subject NPs, but also in object or \isi{oblique} \isi{phrase}s, as in examples \REF{ex:det:94} through \REF{ex:det:97}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndïn numïne \textbf{ndalumopta} ndï mïnapïna. | \gll ndï=n numïne \textbf{anda}=lumo-p-ta ndï mï=na-p-na | \gls 3PL=OBL ditch SG.DIST=put-PFV-COND 3PL 3SG.SUBJ=DETR-be-IRR | \glt `Once [I] have planted them in that ditch, they will be there.’
Content 2: \gsrc Una ngusuwa \textbf{laya} wonlakan! | \gll unan ngusuwa \textbf{ala}=iya won-la-ka-n | \gls 1PL.INCL poor PL.DIST=toward cut-IRR-let-IMP | \glt `Let’s cross over [the river] to those poor folks [on the other side]!’

Knowledge Point: Although the basic function of \isi{demonstrative} determiners is taken to be a means of providing spatial \isi{deixis} from the reference point of the speaker, the actual range of uses of demonstratives is much greater. First, it is not uncommon for a speaker to project a \isi{deictic center} to a point other than the self. Thus, while \isi{demonstrative} words in Ulwa are taken generally to be \isi{egocentric}, a speaker may choose a reference point other than himself or herself in the moment of \isi{speech}. This is common in recounted narratives \REF{ex:det:98}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï amun iwa \textbf{ngalan} mop mo kundan nïpat \textbf{ngatïn}. | \gll nï amun iwa \textbf{ngala}=n ma=u-p ma=u kundan nïpat \textbf{nga}=tï-n | \gls 1SG now basket PL.PROX=OBL 3SG.OBJ=put-PFV 3SG.OBJ=from eel huge SG.PROX=take-PFV | \glt `Now I put these fish trap baskets [down] there and got this huge eel from there.’

Knowledge Point: In example \REF{ex:det:98}, although the \isi{proximal} \isi{deictic} words (ngala= ‘\textsc{pl.prox}’ and nga= ‘\textsc{sg.prox’}) are indeed used with reference to the speaker, they are not used in reference to the speaker’s \isi{location} at the \isi{time} of speaking, but rather to her \isi{location} in the past, when the events being recounted occurred. Projected \isi{deixis} can occur in narratives even when the actor of the clause is different from the narrator of the events, as, for example, in \REF{ex:det:99} and \REF{ex:det:100}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï amun iwa \textbf{ngalan} mop mo kundan nïpat \textbf{ngatïn}. | \gll nï amun iwa \textbf{ngala}=n ma=u-p ma=u kundan nïpat \textbf{nga}=tï-n | \gls 1SG now basket PL.PROX=OBL 3SG.OBJ=put-PFV 3SG.OBJ=from eel huge SG.PROX=take-PFV | \glt `Now I put these fish trap baskets [down] there and got this huge eel from there.’
Content 2: \gsrc Mï i wolka i manji anaw \textbf{ngatïn} … | \gll mï i wolka i ma-nji anaw \textbf{nga}=tï-n | \gls 3SG.SUBJ go.PFV again go.PFV 3SG.OBJ-POSS paddle SG.PROX=take-PFV | \glt `He went, went back, got his motorboat …’
Content 3: \gsrc Anul men i wonmbi \textbf{ngintï} men i. | \gll anul ma=in i wonmbi \textbf{ngin}=tï ma=in i | \gls grassland 3SG.OBJ=in go.PFV tusk DU.PROX=take 3SG.OBJ=in go.PFV | \glt `[He] went into the grass, got these two tusks, and went in.’

Knowledge Point: This phenomenon of projection can further be illustrated with the \isi{locative adverb} mbï ‘here’ (\sectref{sec:8.2.2}), which can signify space near the referent of the clause, even when this is not near the speaker in his or her current \isi{location}, as in example \REF{ex:det:101}.
Content 1: \gsrc Alum mokotïp an mol \textbf{mbïwap}. | \gll alum ma=kot-p an ma=ul \textbf{mbï}-wap | \gls child 3SG.OBJ=break-PFV 1PL.EXCL 3SG.OBJ=with here-be.PST | \glt `She bore a child, and we were there with her.’

Knowledge Point: Demonstratives, although fundamentally spatial, may be extended in their use to have \isi{temporal} \isi{deixis}. Thus, \isi{proximal} forms may be used to refer to \isi{time}s (\isi{metaphor}ically) close to the \isi{present}, whereas \isi{distal} forms signal more (\isi{metaphor}ically) distant \isi{time}, as illustrated by examples \REF{ex:det:102} through \REF{ex:det:106}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ipka \textbf{ndan} matmat mbu ulwape. | \gll ipka \textbf{anda}=n matmat mbï-u ulwa=p-e | \gls before SG.DIST=OBL cemetery here-from nothing=COP-DEP | \glt `In the past, there was no cemetery here.’
Content 2: \gsrc Iwïl \textbf{andan} ma mapta apa ndaytana. | \gll iwïl \textbf{anda}=n ma ma=p-ta apa anda=ita-na | \gls moon SG.DIST=OBL go 3SG.OBJ=be{-cond} house SG.DIST=build-IRR | \glt `Next month [I] will go and build a house there.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:det:106} also illustrates how words like \ili{English} ‘this’, ‘these’, ‘that’, and ‘those’ are often not ideal (or even possible) translations for the \isi{demonstrative} markers. This is because, even though the Ulwa \isi{demonstrative}s serve some \isi{deictic} function of pointing to a place or \isi{time}, they do not necessarily have a definite referent. Thus, in example \REF{ex:det:106}, the translation ‘a house’ is given, since this unbuilt house has no definite referent; the salient information, however, is that the house will be built ‘there’.\footnote{Of course, it is possible that the ‘house’ in this sentence does indeed have a definite referent, just not a real-world one, and that the speaker and hearer can both be thinking of a specific yet-to-be-built house.}
Content 1: \gsrc Iwïl \textbf{andan} ma mapta apa ndaytana. | \gll iwïl \textbf{anda}=n ma ma=p-ta apa anda=ita-na | \gls moon SG.DIST=OBL go 3SG.OBJ=be{-cond} house SG.DIST=build-IRR | \glt `Next month [I] will go and build a house there.’
Content 2: \gsrc Iwïl \textbf{andan} ma mapta apa ndaytana. | \gll iwïl \textbf{anda}=n ma ma=p-ta apa anda=ita-na | \gls moon SG.DIST=OBL go 3SG.OBJ=be{-cond} house SG.DIST=build-IRR | \glt `Next month [I] will go and build a house there.’

Knowledge Point: In addition to spatial and \isi{temporal} \isi{deictic} functions, the \isi{demonstrative} words in Ulwa can serve discourse functions as well, pointing to \isi{speech} itself, whether already spoken or not yet uttered \REF{ex:det:107}.
Content 1: \gsrc Oke li ngata ngusuwa \textbf{nga}: Kayta Amombi Yokombla Yaruwa Kayngam. | \gll oke li ngata ngusuwa \textbf{nga} Kayta Amombi Yokombla Yaruwa Kayngam | \gls ok down grand poor SG.PROX [name] [name] [name] [name] [name] | \glt `OK, the downstream ancestors, the poor things, were as follows: Kayta, Amombi, Yokombla, Yaruwa, and Kayngam.’

Knowledge Point: Demonstrative words may also be used, to similar effect, as determiners modifying the word na ‘talk’, as in examples \REF{ex:det:108}, \REF{ex:det:109}, and \REF{ex:det:110}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ini na \textbf{nga} mï ambip. | \gll ini na \textbf{nga} mï ambi=p | \gls ground talk SG.PROX 3SG.SUBJ big=COP | \glt `This talk about land is big -- it [has gotten] big.’
Content 2: \gsrc Mase na \textbf{nda} una asika matap. | \gll ma=asa-e na \textbf{anda} unan asi-ka ma=ta-p | \gls 3SG.OBJ=hit{-dep} talk SG.DIST 1PL.INCL sit-let 3SG.OBJ=say-PFV | \glt `That talk of [them] killing her – we sat and discussed it.’
Content 3: \gsrc Na anma \textbf{nda}. | \gll na anma \textbf{anda} | \gls talk good SG.DIST | \glt `That’s good talk.’

Knowledge Point: Similarly, when a referent has been introduced, a speaker can refer again to this referent with a \isi{deictic} word. In the text from which examples \REF{ex:det:111} and \REF{ex:det:112} are taken, the speaker introduces a subject with the \isi{subject marker} mï ‘3\textsc{sg.subj’} \REF{ex:det:111}, but shortly thereafter refers again to the same referent with the \isi{demonstrative} word nga ‘\textsc{sg.prox}’ (‘this’) \REF{ex:det:112}.
Content 1: \gsrc Inom \textbf{mï} anganika nganul i. | \gll inom \textbf{mï} anganika ngan=ul i | \gls mother 3SG.SUBJ after 1DU.EXCL=with go.PFV | \glt `Later, the mother came with the two of us.’
Content 2: \gsrc Inom \textbf{nga} nan makïta … | \gll inom \textbf{nga} na=n ma=kï-ta | \gls mother SG.PROX talk=OBL 3SG.OBJ=say-COND | \glt `If this mother tells him …’
Content 3: \gsrc Inom \textbf{mï} anganika nganul i. | \gll inom \textbf{mï} anganika ngan=ul i | \gls mother 3SG.SUBJ after 1DU.EXCL=with go.PFV | \glt `Later, the mother came with the two of us.’
Content 4: \gsrc Inom \textbf{nga} nan makïta … | \gll inom \textbf{nga} na=n ma=kï-ta | \gls mother SG.PROX talk=OBL 3SG.OBJ=say-COND | \glt `If this mother tells him …’

Knowledge Point: Often, however, the \isi{deictic} function of \isi{demonstrative} words is not clear. The choice between nga ‘\textsc{sg.prox}’ (‘this’) and anda ‘\textsc{sg.dist}’ (‘that’), for example, does not always seem to reflect proximity or distance, whether spatial, \isi{temporal}, or narrative. Perhaps speakers make decisions based on desires to signal \isi{metaphor}ical proximity or distance to referents. This seems possible especially when referring to people in general terms -- that is, people who are physically neither close nor far in the event encoded in the clause. Other times, however, it is not at all clear to me why these words are being used, and there could be some degree of \isi{free variation} for speakers in certain circumstances. In sentences \REF{ex:det:113} through \REF{ex:det:118}, the \isi{deictic} function of the \isi{demonstrative} words is unclear.
Content 1: \gsrc Anji ngata \textbf{ngalol} inde. | \gll an-nji ngata \textbf{ngala}=ul inda-e | \gls 1PL-POSS grand PL.PROX=with walk-IPFV | \glt `[We] walked around with our grandparents.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nïnji yawa \textbf{nga} itom ndïnji tana mat nen. | \gll nï-nji yawa \textbf{nga} itom ndï-nji tana ma=tï ni-en | \gls 1SG-POSS uncle SG.PROX father 3PL-POSS axe 3SG.OBJ=take act{-nmlz} | \glt `This uncle of mine was one who got the forefathers’

Knowledge Point: Reference to undoubtedly distant entities, such as the sun or the moon, for example, may be referred to with either \isi{proximal} determiners, as in \REF{ex:det:119} and \REF{ex:det:120}, or \isi{distal} determiners, as in \REF{ex:det:121} and \REF{ex:det:122}; they may alternatively be referred to with the \isi{subject marker} mï ‘3\textsc{sg}’ \REF{ex:det:123} or with no marker at all \REF{ex:det:124}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ane \textbf{nga} sita … | \gll ane \textbf{nga} si-ta | \gls sun SG.PROX push-COND | \glt `Whenever it was dry season …’
Content 2: \gsrc Ango li ma lïmndï ato ane \textbf{ngandïna}. | \gll ango li ma lïmndï ata-u ane \textbf{nga}=andï-na | \gls NEG down go eye up-from sun SG.PROX=see-IRR | \glt `[She] won’t go down and look up at the sun. ’
Content 3: \gsrc A ane \textbf{nda} li namane. | \gll a ane \textbf{anda} li na-ma-n-e | \gls ah sun SG.DIST down DETR-go-IPFV-DEP | \glt `Ah, the sun is setting.’
Content 4: \gsrc Iwïl \textbf{anda} liye wa imba pe. | \gll iwïl \textbf{anda} li-i-e wa imba p-e | \gls moon SG.DIST down-go.PFV-DEP village night be{-ipfv} | \glt `The moon had set; the village was dark.’
Content 5: \gsrc Anwe iwïl \textbf{mï} ata ne ne. | \gll an-we iwïl \textbf{mï} ata na-i na-i | \gls 1PL.EXCL-PART.INT moon 3SG.SUBJ up DETR-go.PFV DETR-go.PFV | \glt `We were alone; the moon rose and rose.’
Content 6: \gsrc Ane namane. | \gll ane na-ma-n-e | \gls sun DETR-go-IPFV-DEP | \glt `The sun is setting.’

Knowledge Point: Although the Christian god is usually referred to with the \isi{proximal} \isi{deictic} word nga ‘\textsc{sg.prox}’ (‘this’) (i.e., ambi nga ‘this big [man]’), it seems also possible to refer to him with the \isi{distal} \isi{deictic} word anda ‘\textsc{sg.dist}’ (‘that’), as illustrated by examples \REF{ex:det:125} through \REF{ex:det:128}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ambi \textbf{nganji} na nga unaniya mbi. | \gll ambi \textbf{nga-nji} na nga unan=iya mbï-i | \gls big SG.PROX-POSS talk SG.PROX 1PL.INCL=toward here-go.PFV | \glt `The word of God has come to us.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ambi \textbf{anda} mat anmbïnalp. | \gll ambi \textbf{anda} ma=tï an-mbï na-lï-p | \gls big SG.DIST 3SG.OBJ=take out-here DETR-put-PFV | \glt `God has revealed him.’

Knowledge Point: In addition to serving their prototypically \isi{deictic} function, demonstratives in Ulwa may be used to indicate that an introduced NP is going to play a key role in the discourse to follow -- that is, even though the NP presents \isi{new information} (i.e., non-\isi{given information}), a form like anda ‘\textsc{sg.dist}’ (‘that’) may be used, as in \REF{ex:det:129}, \REF{ex:det:130}, and \REF{ex:det:131}.
Content 1: \gsrc Awlu ato anmoka \textbf{anda} apïnal ando anmbi. | \gll awlu ata-u anmoka \textbf{anda} apïnal anda=u an-mbï-i | \gls step up-from snake SG.DIST swamp SG.DIST=from out-here-go.PFV | \glt `When [the moon] appeared, a snake came out from the swamp.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nambi wandam ambi \textbf{nda}. | \gll nï-ambi wandam ambi \textbf{anda} | \gls 1SG-TOP jungle big SG.DIST | \glt `As for me, I have a big garden.’
Content 3: \gsrc Mbalus \textbf{anda} ina mane. | \gll mbalus \textbf{anda} i-na ma-n-e | \gls airplane SG.DIST come-IRR go-IPFV-DEP | \glt `An airplane was going to come.’

Knowledge Point: Sentences \REF{ex:det:132} through \REF{ex:det:137} exemplify the use of the demonstratives as \isi{object marker}s.
Content 1: \gsrc Lapun nga lamndu \textbf{ngas}! | \gll lapun nga lamndu \textbf{nga=}asa | \gls old.person SG.PROX pig SG.PROX=hit | \glt `This old man killed this pig!’
Content 2: \gsrc Upan wambana \textbf{lawtata} ndul wa undana. | \gll upan wambana \textbf{ala}=uta-ta ndï=ul wa unda-na | \gls fish.species fish PL.DIST=grind{-cond} 3PL=with village go-IRR | \glt `If [we] catch those fish, [we] will go home with them.’

Knowledge Point: As mentioned, \isi{demonstrative} forms can also function pronominally. They can have this pronominal function, whether serving as subjects, as in examples \REF{ex:det:138}, \REF{ex:det:139}, and \REF{ex:det:140}; or serving as objects, as in examples \REF{ex:det:141} and \REF{ex:det:142}. No distinction is made between \isi{animate} and \isi{inanimate} referents.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Anda} nip. | \gll \textbf{anda} ni-p | \gls SG.DIST die-PFV | \glt `That [one] died.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Ngin} liyu. | \gll \textbf{ngin} li-u | \gls DU.PROX down-put | \glt `These [two] fell.’
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Ala} lamndu masap. | \gll ala lamndu ma=asa-p | \gls PL.DIST pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `Those [ones] killed the pig.’
Content 4: \gsrc Nï lïmndï \textbf{ngala}. | \gll nï lïmndï \textbf{nga=}ala | \gls 1SG eye SG.PROX=see | \glt `I saw this [one].’
Content 5: \gsrc Nï lïmndï \textbf{andinala}. | \gll nï lïmndï \textbf{andin}=ala | \gls 1SG eye DU.DIST=see | \glt `I saw those [two].’

Knowledge Point: These \isi{object-marker} \isi{demonstrative} \isi{pronoun}s may not always be \isi{clitic}s. Examples such as \REF{ex:det:143} and \REF{ex:det:144} illustrate a greater \isi{phonological} separation between \isi{pronoun} and verb -- that is, the sequence in example \REF{ex:det:143} is pronounced [nga.la.i.ta.na] and not \textsuperscript{†}[nga.lay.ta.na]; and the sequence in example \REF{ex:det:144} is pronounced [a.nda.i] and not \textsuperscript{†}[a.nday].
Content 1: \gsrc Apa \textbf{ngala} \textbf{itana} mane. | \gll apa \textbf{ngala} \textbf{ita-na} ma-n-e | \gls house PL.PROX build-IRR go-IPFV-DEP | \glt `[They] were going to build these houses.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ndamape nï anmap nï i \textbf{anda i}. | \gll ndï=ama-p-e nï anma=p nï i \textbf{anda} i | \gls 3PL=eat-PFV-DEP 1SG good=COP 1SG go.PFV SG.DIST go.PFV | \glt `Having taken them, I got better, and I went, went there.’
Content 3: \gsrc Apa \textbf{ngala} \textbf{itana} mane. | \gll apa \textbf{ngala} \textbf{ita-na} ma-n-e | \gls house PL.PROX build-IRR go-IPFV-DEP | \glt `[They] were going to build these houses.’
Content 4: \gsrc Ndamape nï anmap nï i \textbf{anda i}. | \gll ndï=ama-p-e nï anma=p nï i \textbf{anda} i | \gls 3PL=eat-PFV-DEP 1SG good=COP 1SG go.PFV SG.DIST go.PFV | \glt `Having taken them, I got better, and I went, went there.’

Knowledge Point: Demonstrative \isi{pronoun}s can be the subject of a clause that has a noun or \isi{adjective} as the \isi{predicate complement}. Here, their \isi{deictic} function is quite clear, as seen in examples \REF{ex:det:145} through \REF{ex:det:150}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Nga} nïnji apa. | \gll \textbf{nga} nï-nji apa | \gls SG.PROX 1SG-POSS house | \glt `This is my house.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Ala} anmap. | \gll \textbf{ala} anma=p | \gls PL.DIST good=COP | \glt `Those are good.’

Knowledge Point: Demonstrative \isi{pronoun}s are used to refer to human referents (as in ‘this [one]’, ‘those [ones]’, etc.) much more than is common in, say, \ili{English}. In particular, the \isi{plural} \isi{distal} \isi{demonstrative} \isi{pronoun} ala ‘\textsc{pl.dist}’ (‘those’) is often best translated simple as ‘they’ or ‘people’ (or sometimes as ‘other people’), as in examples \REF{ex:det:151} through \REF{ex:det:154}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ala} natana. | \gll \textbf{ala} na-ta-na | \gls PL.DIST DETR-say-IRR | \glt `They were going to have a talk.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Ala} ndute ndame mbïp. | \gll \textbf{ala} ndï=uta-e ndï=ama-e mbï-p | \gls PL.DIST 3PL=grind-IPFV 3PL=eat-IPFV here-be | \glt `People catch them and eat them here.’

Knowledge Point: Furthermore the \isi{plural} \isi{distal} \isi{demonstrative} ala ‘\textsc{pl.dist}’ (‘those’) may be used instead of the second \isi{plural} \isi{personal pronoun} un ‘\textsc{2pl}’, when addressing groups of people, as in examples \REF{ex:det:155} through \REF{ex:det:158}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ala} wokïn anda unalu mbiyen anda ango i? | \gll \textbf{ala} wokïn anda unan=lu mbï-i-en anda ango i | \gls PL.DIST big.man SG.DIST 1PL.INCL=with here-go-NMLZ SG.DIST which go.PFV | \glt `You folks, that big man who came with us -- where did that [man] go?’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Ala} ndïn anjikake ndï se? | \gll \textbf{ala} ndï=n anjikaka-e ndï sa-e | \gls PL.DIST 3PL=OBL how-DEP 3PL cry-IPFV | \glt `Folks, what have [you done] with them, such that they are crying?’

Knowledge Point: In fact, combined with the form -nji ‘thing’, the \isi{demonstrative} ala ‘\textsc{pl.dist}’ (‘those’) can even be used in \is{possession} possessive constructions -- that is, alanji \linebreak ‘\textsc{pl.dist-poss}’ (‘those [people]’s’) in place of ndïnji ‘\textsc{3pl-poss}’ (‘their’), often with the sense of ‘other people’s. This is illustrated by examples \REF{ex:det:159}, \REF{ex:det:160}, and \REF{ex:det:161}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ambwat \textbf{alanji} Monde. | \gll Ambwat \textbf{ala-nji} Monde | \gls Kambot PL.DIST-POSS [name] | \glt `The Kambot people’s [ancestor] was Monde.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Alanji} wo ndï makape. | \gll \textbf{ala-nji} wa ndï maka=p-e | \gls PL.DIST-POSS village 3PL thus=COP{-dep} | \glt `Other people’s villages are like that.’
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{alanji} amba nda | \gll \textbf{ala-nji} amba anda | \gls PL.DIST-POSS mens.house SG.DIST | \glt `that magic of other people’

Knowledge Point: On \isi{semantic} grounds, words that express concepts such as ‘much’, ‘many’, ‘few’, ‘all’, ‘some’, and so on may be considered quantifiers. The words that express these concepts in Ulwa mostly pattern \isi{syntactic}ally with words in other classes, namely \isi{adjective}s. There is at least one word, however, that warrants placement in a separate \isi{quantifier} class, since it displays some unique \isi{syntactic} properties. This word is wopa ‘all’. The major quantity-denoting words are given in \REF{ex:det:202}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The word wopa ‘all’ can function as an \isi{adjective}, meaning ‘whole’, ‘entire’, or ‘full’. Like all \isi{adjective}s, its canonical position is immediately following the noun that it modifies (\sectref{sec:5.1}). If there is a \isi{subject marker}, \isi{object marker}, or other \isi{determiner} present, then the \isi{adjective} wopa ‘all’ precedes this word. In this usage, it has a \isi{singular} (as opposed to \isi{plural}) meaning -- that is, it means something like ‘all of something’ or ‘the whole’. Accordingly, as in examples \REF{ex:det:162}, \REF{ex:det:163}, and \REF{ex:det:164}, NPs containing the \isi{attributive adjective} wopa ‘all’ are followed by \isi{singular} determiners (e.g., the \isi{subject marker} mï ‘3\textsc{sg.subj}’ or the \isi{demonstrative} \isi{object marker} anda= ‘\textsc{sg.dist’).}
Content 1: \gsrc Im \textbf{wopa} mï liyu. | \gll im \textbf{wopa} mï li-u | \gls tree all 3SG.SUBJ down-put | \glt `The whole tree fell.’
Content 2: \gsrc Utam \textbf{wopa} mï tembip. | \gll utam \textbf{wopa} mï tembi=p | \gls yam all 3SG.SUBJ bad=COP | \glt `The entire yam is rotten.’
Content 3: \gsrc Ndï unan wat u apïn \textbf{wopa} ndatïne … | \gll ndï unan=n wat u apïn \textbf{wopa} anda=tï-n-e | \gls 3PL 1PL.INCL=OBL atop from fire all SG.DIST=take-PFV-DEP | \glt `And once they have gotten the full fire from above us …’

Knowledge Point: Like all \isi{adjective}s, wopa ‘all’ may also function as a substantive (\sectref{sec:5.3}). In example \REF{ex:det:165}, wopa ‘all’ is followed by the \isi{plural} \isi{subject marker} ndï `3\textsc{pl}’, because it is referring to multiple whole things (in this sentence, fish).
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Wopa} ndï ngamana. | \gll \textbf{wopa} ndï nga=ma-na | \gls all 3PL SG.PROX=go-IRR | \glt `The whole [ones] will go here.’

Knowledge Point: As a \isi{syntactic}ally distinct \isi{quantifier}, however, wopa ‘all’ refers to all members of a group or set of things. Thus it fills the function of a \is{universal quantifier} \isi{collective universal quantifier}. Instead of preceding the \isi{subject marker} (or subject \isi{pronoun}), the \isi{quantifier} follows it. If the \isi{quantifier} wopa ‘all’ can be analyzed as belonging to the NP, then it is the only NP-internal element allowed to follow a \isi{subject marker} (or \isi{object marker}); however, it may be better to analyze the \isi{quantifier} as sitting \isi{syntactic}ally outside the NP. In sentences \REF{ex:det:166}, \REF{ex:det:167}, and \REF{ex:det:168}, wopa ‘all’ follows the \isi{plural} \isi{subject marker} ndï `3\textsc{pl}’.
Content 1: \gsrc Im ndï \textbf{wopa} liyu. | \gll im ndï \textbf{wopa} li-u | \gls tree 3PL all down-put | \glt `All the trees fell.’
Content 2: \gsrc Utam ndï \textbf{wopa} tembip. | \gll utam ndï \textbf{wopa} tembi=p | \gls yam 3PL all bad=COP | \glt `All the yams are rotten.’
Content 3: \gsrc Nji ndï \textbf{wopa} men pe. | \gll nji ndï \textbf{wopa} ma=in p-e | \gls thing 3PL all 3SG.OBJ=in be{-ipfv} | \glt `All [his] possessions are in it.’

Knowledge Point: Examples \REF{ex:det:169}, \REF{ex:det:170}, and \REF{ex:det:171} illustrate that the \isi{quantifier} wopa ‘all’ can appear after \isi{pronoun}s as well as after \isi{subject marker}s. Such \isi{pronoun}s are always \isi{plural}.
Content 1: \gsrc Una \textbf{wopa} map. | \gll unan \textbf{wopa} ma=p | \gls 1PL.INCL all 3SG.OBJ=be | \glt `We all stay there.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ndï \textbf{wopa} wombïn ne. | \gll ndï \textbf{wopa} wombïn=n ni-e | \gls 3PL all work=OBL act-IPFV | \glt (a) ‘They are all working.’\\’
Content 3: \gsrc Ndambi \textbf{wopa} anala mbïp. | \gll ndï-ambi \textbf{wopa} an=ala mbï-p | \gls 3PL-TOP all 1PL.EXCL=for here-be | \glt `As for them, they all stayed for our sake.’

Knowledge Point: As a \isi{quantifier}, wopa ‘all’ has a rigid post-NP position. Attempts to raise the \isi{quantifier} overtly to a position within the NP (that is, between the noun and \isi{subject marker}) result in an \is{adjective} adjectival interpretation of the word (that is, ‘whole’, ‘full’, ‘complete’, etc.), as shown in \REF{ex:det:172} and \REF{ex:det:173}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ankam ndï \textbf{wopa} wandam i. | \gll ankam ndï \textbf{wopa} wandam i | \gls person 3PL all jungle go.PFV | \glt `All the people went to the jungle.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ankam \textbf{wopa} ndï wandam i. | \gll ankam \textbf{wopa} ndï wandam i | \gls person all 3PL jungle go.PFV | \glt ‘The whole people went to the jungle.’

Knowledge Point: Although the \isi{quantifier} wopa ‘all’ must always follow the entire NP (including the \isi{subject marker}), in \isi{negative} clauses it may either precede \REF{ex:det:174} or follow \REF{ex:det:175} the \isi{negative} marker ango ‘\textsc{neg}’. The fact that it may follow the \isi{negator} is further indication that it does not properly belong within the NP \isi{syntactic}ally, since the \isi{negator} word does not belong \isi{syntactic}ally to the NP.
Content 1: \gsrc Ankam ndï \textbf{wopa} ango wandam i. | \gll ankam ndï \textbf{wopa} ango wandam i | \gls person 3PL all NEG jungle go.PFV | \glt `All the people did not go to the jungle.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ankam ndï ango \textbf{wopa} wandam i. | \gll ankam ndï ango \textbf{wopa} wandam i | \gls person 3PL NEG all jungle go.PFV | \glt `All the people did not go to the jungle.’

Knowledge Point: Sentences \REF{ex:det:174} and \REF{ex:det:175} have the same meaning. Indeed, the scopal relationship between the \isi{negator} and the \isi{quantifier} is also the same -- and, in both cases, ambivalent. That is, either may have \isi{scope} over the other, producing either the possible interpretation that ‘not all (i.e., some) people went to the jungle’ or the other possible interpretation that ‘no people went to the jungle’. In example \REF{ex:det:176}, only context reveals that ango wopa ‘not all’ implies ‘no one’ as opposed to implying ‘some’.
Content 1: \gsrc Ankam ndï \textbf{wopa} ango wandam i. | \gll ankam ndï \textbf{wopa} ango wandam i | \gls person 3PL all NEG jungle go.PFV | \glt `All the people did not go to the jungle.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ankam ndï ango \textbf{wopa} wandam i. | \gll ankam ndï ango \textbf{wopa} wandam i | \gls person 3PL NEG all jungle go.PFV | \glt `All the people did not go to the jungle.’
Content 3: \gsrc Ndï \textbf{ango wopa} mol lop. | \gll ndï \textbf{ango} \textbf{wopa} ma=ul lo-p | \gls 3PL NEG all 3SG.OBJ=with go-PFV | \glt `They all did not go with him.’

Knowledge Point: At times, wopa ‘all’ may alternatively be translated as ‘everything’ or ‘everyone’. In these instances, wopa ‘all’ also follows \isi{subject marker}s or \isi{pronoun}s (as when the word functions elsewhere as a \isi{quantifier}), as in \REF{ex:det:177} and \REF{ex:det:178}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nji ndï \textbf{wopa} liyu. | \gll nji ndï \textbf{wopa} li-u | \gls thing 3PL all down-put | \glt `Everything fell.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ala \textbf{wopa} wandam i. | \gll ala \textbf{wopa} wandam i | \gls PL.DIST all jungle go.PFV | \glt `Everyone went to the jungle.’

Knowledge Point: However, it may also function somewhat like a \isi{pronoun}, forming its own NP \REF{ex:det:179}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Wopa} malanda. | \gll \textbf{wopa} ma=la-nda | \gls all 3SG.OBJ=eat-IRR | \glt `All would eat it.’

Knowledge Point: One of the most interesting aspects of the \isi{syntactic} positioning of the \isi{quantifier} wopa ‘all’, however, is the fact that it follows not only \isi{subject marker}s, but also \isi{object marker}s. It is thus the only element known to intercede between \isi{object-marker} \isi{clitic}s and their associated verbs. Sentences \REF{ex:det:180} through \REF{ex:det:183} illustrate this unusual placement of wopa ‘all’.
Content 1: \gsrc Inom mï mïnda \textbf{nduwopa} wananda. | \gll inom mï mïnda ndï=\textbf{wopa} wana-nda | \gls mother 3SG.SUBJ banana 3PL=all cook-IRR | \glt `Mother will cook all the bananas.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï lïmndï \textbf{alawopa} ala. | \gll nï lïmndï ala=\textbf{wopa} ala | \gls 1SG eye PL.DIST=all see | \glt `I saw everyone.’

Knowledge Point: When preceding the \isi{object marker}, however, wopa ‘all’ can only have an \is{adjective} adjectival interpretation \REF{ex:det:184}.
Content 1: \gsrc Inom mï mïnda \textbf{wopa} nduwananda. | \gll inom mï mïnda \textbf{wopa} ndï=wana-nda | \gls mother 3SG.SUBJ banana all 3PL=cook-IRR | \glt `Mother will cook the whole bananas.’

Knowledge Point: The \is{universal quantifier} \isi{collective universal quantifier} wopa ‘all’ may be contrasted, both formally and \isi{syntactic}ally, with the \is{universal quantifier} \isi{distributive universal quantifier} nunu ‘every’. Unlike other modifiers, such as \isi{adjective}s (\sectref{sec:5.1}; cf. tïngïn ‘many’), and unlike the \isi{quantifier} wopa ‘all’, the \isi{quantifier} nunu ‘every’ occurs before the noun it modifies. Thus, like wopa ‘all’, nunu ‘every’ may exist in a class of its own. The use of nunu ‘every’ is illustrated by examples \REF{ex:det:185}, \REF{ex:det:186}, and \REF{ex:det:187}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Nunu} njin molnda mane. | \gll \textbf{nunu} nji=n ma=lu-nda ma-n-e | \gls every thing=OBL 3SG.OBJ=put-IRR go-IPFV-DEP | \glt `[I] am going to plant everything there.’
Content 2: \gsrc Wa \textbf{nunu} wa ule. | \gll wa \textbf{nunu} wa u-lo-e | \gls just every village from-go-IPFV | \glt `[They] just go around in every village.’
Content 3: \gsrc A \textbf{nunu} wombïn tembi ndambilakan! | \gll a \textbf{nunu} wombïn tembi ndï-ambi=la-ka-n | \gls ah every work bad 3PL-TOP=IRR-let-IMP | \glt `Ah, every bad job -- forget about them!’

Knowledge Point: Other \isi{semantic}ally quantifier-like words do not occur between \isi{object marker}s and verbs, as wopa ‘all’ does; nor do they occur prenominally, as nunu ‘every’ does. Rather, they behave more like prototypical property-denoting words -- that is, they follow the \isi{head noun} of an NP and precede any \isi{subject marker} or \isi{object marker}. For example, when kuma ‘some’ modifies an object NP, it occurs before the \isi{object marker} (when present), as in \REF{ex:det:188} and \REF{ex:det:189}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï lamndu \textbf{kuma} ndasap. | \gll nï lamndu \textbf{kuma} ndï=asa-p | \gls 1SG pig some 3PL=hit-PFV | \glt `I killed some pigs.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï lïmndï tïn \textbf{kuma} ndala. | \gll nï lïmndï tïn \textbf{kuma} ndï=ala | \gls 1SG eye dog some 3PL=see | \glt `I saw some dogs.’

Knowledge Point: In examples \REF{ex:det:188} and \REF{ex:det:189}, kuma ‘some’ could also have the reading ‘a few’ (that is, ‘some’ as opposed to ‘many’). For the sense ‘some of’ (that is, a \isi{partitive} quantity), the \isi{postposition} ul ‘with’ is employed, as in \REF{ex:det:190}, \REF{ex:det:191}, and \REF{ex:det:192}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï lamndu \textbf{kuma} ndasap. | \gll nï lamndu \textbf{kuma} ndï=asa-p | \gls 1SG pig some 3PL=hit-PFV | \glt `I killed some pigs.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï lïmndï tïn \textbf{kuma} ndala. | \gll nï lïmndï tïn \textbf{kuma} ndï=ala | \gls 1SG eye dog some 3PL=see | \glt `I saw some dogs.’
Content 3: \gsrc Nï lïmndï tïn \textbf{ndul} \textbf{kuma} ndala. | \gll nï lïmndï tïn ndï=\textbf{ul} \textbf{kuma} ndï=ala | \gls 1SG eye dog 3PL=with some 3PL=see | \glt `I saw some of the dogs.’
Content 4: \gsrc Nï utam \textbf{ndul} \textbf{kuma} amap. | \gll nï utam ndï=\textbf{ul} \textbf{kuma} ama-p | \gls 1SG yam 3PL=with some eat-PFV | \glt `I ate some of the yams.’
Content 5: \gsrc An lamndu \textbf{ndul} \textbf{kuma} asap. | \gll an lamndu ndï=\textbf{ul} \textbf{kuma} asa-p | \gls 1PL.EXCL pig 3PL=with some hit-PFV | \glt `We killed some of the pigs.’

Knowledge Point: Like other modifiers, kuma ‘some’ can function as a substantive, whether in a subject NP, as in \REF{ex:det:193} and \REF{ex:det:194}; in a \isi{direct object} NP, as in \REF{ex:det:195} and \REF{ex:det:196}; or in an \isi{oblique} NP, as in \REF{ex:det:197}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Kuma} la woyambïn alanji wandam ala nakap. | \gll \textbf{kuma} ala woyambïn ala-nji wandam ala na-kï-p | \gls some PL.DIST pointlessly PL.DIST{-poss} jungle PL.DIST DETR-say-PFV | \glt `Some people claimed absurdly that those are their jungles.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Kuma} mo ato anmbundata undana. | \gll \textbf{kuma} ma=u ata-u an-mbï-unda-ta unda-na | \gls some 3SG.OBJ=from up-from out-here-go{-cond} go-IRR | \glt `If some go out from there, [they] will go.’
Content 3: \gsrc Ndï \textbf{kuma} ndït nïnane nï wolka i. | \gll ndï \textbf{kuma} ndï=tï nï-na-n-e nï wolka i | \gls 3PL some 3PL=take 1SG=give-PFV-DEP 1SG again go.PFV | \glt `They gave me some and I in turn went.’
Content 4: \gsrc Mï \textbf{kuma} ndïnkap niya i. | \gll mï \textbf{kuma} ndï=nïkï-p nï=iya i | \gls 3SG.SUBJ some 3PL=dig-PFV 1SG=toward go.PFV | \glt `She dug some out and came to me.’
Content 5: \gsrc Min mape \textbf{kuman} upe. | \gll min ma=p-e \textbf{kuma}=n u-p-e | \gls 3DU 3SG.OBJ=be{-dep} some=OBL put-PFV-DEP | \glt `The two are there and [they] planted some.’

Knowledge Point: Note the use of \isi{subject marker}s and \isi{object marker}s. While kuma ‘some’ patterns mostly like other \isi{adjective}s, there is at least one quirk in its \isi{syntactic} patterning. To express a \isi{partitive} sense in the first \isi{person} or second \isi{person} (i.e., ‘some of us’, ‘some of you’, etc.), kuma ‘some’ is placed after the relevant \isi{pronoun}, as in \REF{ex:det:198} and \REF{ex:det:199}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Una kuma} apa mawnde isal monombam awe. | \gll \textbf{unan} \textbf{kuma} apa ma=unda-e i-si-al monombam aw-e | \gls 1PL.INCL some house 3SG.OBJ=go-IPFV hand-push-PFV forehead put-IPFV | \glt `Some of us go to church and pray.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Un kuma} anangani pe imot aye. | \gll \textbf{un} \textbf{kuma} an=angani p-e imot a-e | \gls 2PL some 1PL.EXCL=behind be{-dep} log break-IPFV | \glt `Some of you are behind us, breaking firewood.’

Knowledge Point: Often, kuma ‘some’ is used in contrastive statements, providing a \isi{correlative} structure (i.e., ‘some … others …’), as in \REF{ex:det:200} and \REF{ex:det:201}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Kuma} matïna \textbf{kuma} manakam. | \gll \textbf{kuma} ma=tï-na \textbf{kuma} ma=na-kamb | \gls some 3SG.OBJ=take-IRR some 3SG.OBJ=DETR-shun | \glt `Some wanted to get her; others didn’t want it.’
Content 2: \gsrc An \textbf{kuma} matane \textbf{kuma} an mama u manke itïm awe. | \gll an \textbf{kuma} ma=ta-n-e \textbf{kuma} an mama u ma=nïkï-e itïm aw-e | \gls 1PL.EXCL some 3SG.OBJ=say-IPFV-DEP some 1PL.EXCL mouth from 3SG.OBJ=dig-DEP trash put{-ipfv} | \glt `Some of us are saying it; but others of us are cutting it [= this good message] out of [our] mouths and putting [it] into the trash.’

Knowledge Point: In addition to wopa ‘all’, nunu ‘every’, and kuma ‘some’ -- all of which, to varying degrees, behave unusually \isi{syntactic}ally -- there are several other words in Ulwa that have quantity-related meanings. First, the principal means of expressing a small amount or number is the word ilum ‘piece’, which I consider primarily to be a noun, but which can also function as a modifier along with other nouns in an NP. Its various uses are illustrated by examples \REF{ex:det:203} through \REF{ex:det:206}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï ndïn u ma \textbf{ilum} kotïn. | \gll nï ndï=n u ma \textbf{ilum} ko=tï-n | \gls 1SG 3PL=OBL from 3SG.OBJ piece INDF=take-PFV | \glt `I got a piece of it [= tobacco] from them.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï nji \textbf{ilumnï} molnda. | \gll nï nji \textbf{ilum}=nï ma=lu-nda | \gls 1SG thing piece=OBL 3SG.OBJ=put-IRR | \glt `I will plant a few things there.’

Knowledge Point: The word kekaka ‘one each’ may also be used to express a limited number.\footnote{This word has the alternative form kwekaka ‘one each’.} The word seems to have derived as a \isi{calque} from \ili{Tok Pisin} wanwan ‘one each’. It behaves primarily like an \isi{adverb}, as in \REF{ex:det:207} and \REF{ex:det:208}.
Content 1: \gsrc An ango mïka \textbf{kekaka} inde. | \gll an ango maka \textbf{kekaka} inda-e | \gls 1PL.EXCL NEG thus one.each walk-IPFV | \glt `We wouldn’t walk one by one.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ndï unanï \textbf{kekaka} inap. | \gll ndï unan=nï \textbf{kekaka} ina-p | \gls 3PL 1PL.INCL=OBL one.each get-PFV | \glt `They had just a few of us.’

Knowledge Point: To express large non-countable quantities, \isi{adjective}s such as ambi ‘big’ are used, as in \REF{ex:det:209} and \REF{ex:det:210}.
Content 1: \gsrc Inim \textbf{ambi} keka i. | \gll inim \textbf{ambi} keka i | \gls water big completely go.PFV | \glt `A lot of water has gone.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ango ndïn wombasa anga \textbf{ambi} moke. | \gll ango ndï=n wombasa anga \textbf{ambi} moko-e | \gls NEG 3PL=OBL clay.pot side big take-IPFV | \glt `[They] don’t get lots of money with them.’

Knowledge Point: For large countable quantities, the word tïngïn ‘many’ is used. It patterns for the most part with other modifiers (i.e., \isi{adjective}s). Namely, it can appear after nouns and precede \isi{subject marker}s or \isi{object marker}s. Like other modifiers, it can also serve as a substantive (i.e., as the \isi{head} of a \isi{noun phrase}). That said, there does seem to be a tendency for \isi{object marker}s to be omitted from NPs containing (or consisting exclusively of) tïngïn ‘many’. Perhaps this suggests that tïngïn ‘many’ behaves differently from other modifiers. Alternatively it may simply support the idea that there is a correlation between lack of \isi{object marker}s and lack of \isi{definiteness} (\sectref{sec:7.2}). Sentences \REF{ex:det:211} through \REF{ex:det:214} exemplify the use of tïngïn ‘many’.
Content 1: \gsrc Ulum ndï ankam \textbf{tïngïn} ndame. | \gll ulum ndï ankam \textbf{tïngïn} ndï=ama-e | \gls palm 3PL person many 3PL=eat-IPFV | \glt `The sago palms -- many people are eating them.’
Content 2: \gsrc Anambi ango uta \textbf{tïngïn} asap. | \gll an-ambi ango uta \textbf{tïngïn} asa-p | \gls 1PL.EXCL-TOP NEG bird many hit-PFV | \glt `As for us, we didn’t kill many birds.’

Knowledge Point: The numerals ‘six’ through ‘nine’ usually contain verbal elements. Various \isi{periphrases} are possible, but typically they express the notion that numbers (probably in origin palm fronds or other counters) have been ‘cut’ and ‘added’ to (or ‘put atop’) the number five. Thus, one verbal expression of the number six is literally analyzable as in \REF{ex:det:215}.
Content 1: \gsrc angay kwe kwe mowon ndïwatlïp | \gll anga-i kwe kwe ma=won ndï=wat-lï-p | \gls side-hand one one 3SG.OBJ=cut 3PL=atop-put-PFV | \glt `one side of hand [= five]; [someone] cut one and put [it] atop them’

Knowledge Point: The expressions for the numbers seven \REF{ex:det:216}, eight \REF{ex:det:217}, and nine \REF{ex:det:218} may be analyzed similarly.
Content 1: \gsrc angay kwe nini minwon ndïwatlïp | \gll anga-i kwe nini min=won ndï=wat-lï-p | \gls side-hand one two 3DU=cut 3PL=atop-put-PFV | \glt `one side of hand [= five]; [someone] cut two and put [them] atop them’
Content 2: \gsrc angay kwe lele ndïwon ndïwatlïp | \gll anga-i kwe lele ndï=won ndï=wat-lï-p | \gls side-hand one three 3PL=cut 3PL=atop-put-PFV | \glt `one side of hand [= five]; [someone] cut three and put [them] atop them’
Content 3: \gsrc angay kwe watangïnila ndïwon ndïwatlïp | \gll anga-i kwe watangïnila ndï=won ndï=wat-lï-p | \gls side-hand one four 3PL=cut 3PL=atop-put-PFV | \glt `one side of hand [= five]; [someone] cut four and put [them] atop them’

Knowledge Point: Other \isi{periphrases} are possible to express sums larger than five. In example \REF{ex:det:219} the speaker uses forms similar to those in \REF{ex:det:215}, but with the alternative form of the word for ‘one’; in example \REF{ex:det:220}, however, instead of using the \isi{metaphor} of ‘cutting’, the speaker uses the \isi{metaphor} of numbers being ‘thrown’ atop each other (i.e., ‘added’).
Content 1: \gsrc Lucy mï manji \textbf{angay kwa kwe mowon ndïwatlïp}. | \gll Lucy mï ma-nji \textbf{angay} \textbf{kwa} \textbf{kwe} \textbf{ma=won} \textbf{ndï=wat-lï-p} | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ 3SG.OBJ-POSS five one one 3SG.OBJ=cut 3PL=atop-put-PFV | \glt `Lucy has six [children].’
Content 2: \gsrc angay kwe kwe mowon ndïwatlïp | \gll anga-i kwe kwe ma=won ndï=wat-lï-p | \gls side-hand one one 3SG.OBJ=cut 3PL=atop-put-PFV | \glt `one side of hand [= five]; [someone] cut one and put [it] atop them’
Content 3: \gsrc Nï nïnji tawatïp \textbf{angay kwe nini top ndïwatlïp}. | \gll nï nï-nji tawatïp \textbf{angay} \textbf{kwe} \textbf{nini} \textbf{top} \textbf{ndï=wat-lï-p} | \gls 1SG 1SG-POSS child five one two throw 3PL=atop-put-PFV | \glt ‘I have seven children.’

Knowledge Point: When modifying \isi{noun phrase}s, \isi{cardinal numeral}s occur in the same position as (other) \isi{adjective}s -- that is, immediately following the \isi{noun phrase}. Numerals can modify either subjects or objects; in subject NPs, the \isi{subject marker} is somewhat unnecessary (at least in terms of it serving its common function of indexing \isi{number} -- \isi{singular}, \isi{dual}, or \isi{plural}), and it is thus often omitted, as in \REF{ex:det:221} and \REF{ex:det:222}.
Content 1: \gsrc Tïn \textbf{nini} utam mamap. | \gll tïn \textbf{nini} utam ma=ama-p | \gls dog two yam 3SG.OBJ=eat-PFV | \glt `Two dogs ate the yam.’
Content 2: \gsrc Tïn \textbf{lele} utam mamap. | \gll tïn \textbf{lele} utam ma=ama-p | \gls dog three yam 3SG.OBJ=eat-PFV | \glt `Three dogs ate the yam.’

Knowledge Point: Numerals are not often used to indicate the \isi{number} of referents in a subject, however. Indeed, the ubiquitous \isi{subject marker}s often offer clues to the quantity of multiple referents in a subject NP, especially when the \isi{number} of referents is exactly two, as in example \REF{ex:det:223}, which may be contrasted with example \REF{ex:det:224}, in which the \isi{number} of referents is more than two.
Content 1: \gsrc Tïn \textbf{min} awal wandam i. | \gll tïn \textbf{min} awal wandam i | \gls dog 3DU yesterday jungle go.PFV | \glt `Two dogs went to the jungle yesterday.’
Content 2: \gsrc Tïn \textbf{ndï} awal wandam i. | \gll tïn \textbf{ndï} awal wandam i | \gls dog 3PL yesterday jungle go.PFV | \glt `[Three or more] dogs went to the jungle yesterday.’

Knowledge Point: Despite the redundancy, it is, however, possible for the \isi{dual} \isi{subject marker} to appear alongside the \isi{numeral} nini ‘two’ \REF{ex:det:225}.
Content 1: \gsrc Manji nungol \textbf{nini min} ndïlope. | \gll ma-nji nungol \textbf{nini} \textbf{min} ndï=lo-p-e | \gls 3SG.OBJ-POSS child two 3DU 3PL=go-PFV-DEP | \glt `His two sons went around in them [= jungle areas].’

Knowledge Point: When modifying object NPs, the \isi{numeral} (again, not commonly used in discourse), also appears immediately following the NP, as in \REF{ex:det:226} and \REF{ex:det:227}.
Content 1: \gsrc Tïn mï mïnda (\textbf{nini}) minamap. | \gll tïn mï mïnda (\textbf{nini}) min=ama-p | \gls dog 3SG.SUBJ banana (two) 3DU=eat-PFV | \glt `The dog ate two bananas.’
Content 2: \gsrc Tïn mï mïnda (\textbf{lele}) ndamap. | \gll tïn mï mïnda (\textbf{lele}) ndï=ama-p | \gls dog 3SG.SUBJ banana (three) 3PL=eat-PFV | \glt `The dog ate (three) bananas.’

Knowledge Point: Thus \isi{object marker}s, which often identify the \isi{number} of direct-object referents, also frequently render the use of \isi{cardinal numeral}s redundant. Of course, for \isi{number}s greater than two, numerals are useful for specifying exact quantities, as in \REF{ex:det:228}.
Content 1: \gsrc Maple mï apa mo mïnda \textbf{lele} ndïtïna. | \gll Maple mï apa ma=u mïnda \textbf{lele} ndï=tï-na | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ house 3SG.OBJ=from banana three 3PL=take-IRR | \glt `Maple will take three bananas from the house.’

Knowledge Point: Similarly, the \isi{numeral} kwe {\textasciitilde} kwa ‘one’ may be used to modify the object of a verb along with the \isi{object marker} ma= ‘3\textsc{sg.obj}’, as in \REF{ex:det:229}. In such instances, the \isi{indefinite} \isi{object marker} ko= ‘\textsc{indf}’ is not used (\sectref{sec:7.2}).
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Kwe} mat manane. | \gll \textbf{kwe} ma=tï ma=na-n-e | \gls one 3SG.OBJ=take 3SG.OBJ=give-PFV-DEP | \glt `[They] gave him one [= a fruit].’

Knowledge Point: Thus, \isi{subject marker}s and \isi{object marker}s typically reflect the same \isi{number} that is expressed by a \isi{numeral} in the same NP. However, when numerals express higher numbers, which are \isi{periphrastic}, a \isi{determiner} can actually agree with the final component number, as in \REF{ex:det:230}, where the \isi{dual} \isi{object marker} min= ‘3\textsc{du}’ agrees with just the final ‘two’ component of the \isi{phrase} for ‘ten’.
Content 1: \gsrc Angay \textbf{nini} \textbf{minat}. | \gll angay \textbf{nini} \textbf{min}=atï | \gls five two 3DU=hit | \glt `Ten [days] passed.’

Knowledge Point: It could be argued that the \isi{object marker} in \REF{ex:det:230} should properly be ndï= ‘3\textsc{pl}’ and not min= ‘3\textsc{du}’, since the object is a \isi{number} greater than two (‘ten days’). However, assuming that this sentence is grammatical, the use of the \isi{dual} marker could be taken as evidence that numeral formulations such as angay nini ‘ten’ are not \isi{lexical}ized, but rather are analyzable periphrases (e.g., this phrase has the literal meaning ‘two fives’).
Content 1: \gsrc Angay \textbf{nini} \textbf{minat}. | \gll angay \textbf{nini} \textbf{min}=atï | \gls five two 3DU=hit | \glt `Ten [days] passed.’

Knowledge Point: As modifiers, numerals can also be \isi{predicate complement}s to subjects, serving as the verbal element of a clause. They can thus host the \isi{copular enclitic} =p ‘\textsc{cop}’ (\sectref{sec:10.2}) or be followed by the \isi{suppletive} \isi{past}-\isi{tense} \isi{locative verb} wap ‘be.\textsc{pst’} (\sectref{sec:10.4}). \is{existential predication} Existential constructions specifying a particular \isi{number} of referents can take this form, as seen in \REF{ex:det:231}, \REF{ex:det:232}, and \REF{ex:det:233}.
Content 1: \gsrc Tïn ndï \textbf{lelep}. | \gll tïn ndï \textbf{lele=p} | \gls dog 3PL three=COP | \glt `There are three dogs.’
Content 2: \gsrc Tïn ndï \textbf{lelepïna}. | \gll tïn ndï \textbf{lele=p-na} | \gls dog 3PL three=COP-IRR | \glt `There will be three dogs.’
Content 3: \gsrc Tïn ndï ipka \textbf{lele wap}. | \gll tïn ndï ipka \textbf{lele} \textbf{wap} | \gls dog 3PL before three be.PST | \glt `There were three dogs before.’

Knowledge Point: There is no distinct set of \isi{ordinal numeral}s in Ulwa. The relative ordering of events must be accomplished with forms of the verbs ip ka- ‘precede’ or angani ka- ‘follow’ (\sectref{sec:9.2.3}). Forms of these verbs that are \isi{nominalize}d with the \isi{suffix} -en ‘\textsc{nmlz}’ (\sectref{sec:3.2}) can be paired in \isi{apposition} with NPs, as in examples \REF{ex:det:234} and \REF{ex:det:235}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nïnji \textbf{ipken} yana mï nip. | \gll nï-nji \textbf{ip-ka-en} yana mï ni-p | \gls 1SG-POSS nose-let-NMLZ woman 3SG.SUBJ die-PFV | \glt `My first wife died.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nïnji \textbf{anganiken} yana\textbf{ }mï nip. | \gll nï-nji \textbf{angani-ka-en} yana mï ni-p | \gls 1SG-POSS behind-let-NMLZ woman 3SG.SUBJ die-PFV | \glt `My second wife died.’

Knowledge Point: Consider the contrast between the \isi{adverb}s ipka ‘before, earlier, first’ \REF{ex:det:236} or anganika ‘after, later, soon’ \REF{ex:det:238} with the related \isi{nominalize}d verb forms in examples \REF{ex:det:237} and \REF{ex:det:239}, respectively.
Content 1: \gsrc Kapos mï \textbf{ipka} lamndu masap. | \gll Kapos mï \textbf{ipka} lamndu ma=asa-p | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ before pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `Kapos killed the pig first.’
Content 2: \gsrc Kapos mï \textbf{anganika} lamndu masap. | \gll Kapos mï \textbf{anganika} lamndu ma=asa-p | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ after pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `Kapos killed the pig afterwards.’
Content 3: \gsrc Kapos mï \textbf{ipken} lamndu masap. | \gll Kapos mï \textbf{ip-ka-en} lamndu ma=asa-p | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ nose-let-NMLZ pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `Kapos killed the first pig.’
Content 4: \gsrc Nomnga mï \textbf{anganiken} lamndu masap. | \gll Nomnga mï \textbf{angani-ka-en} lamndu ma=asa-p | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ behind-let-NMLZ pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `Nomnga killed the second pig.’

Knowledge Point: The notion of ‘third’ may be denoted by the \isi{dual} \isi{object marker} min= ‘\textsc{3du}’ \isi{clitic}izing to the verb angani ka- ‘follow’ \REF{ex:det:240}, whereas ordinal notions greater than ‘third’ would be suggested by the \isi{plural} \isi{object marker} ndï= ‘\textsc{3pl}’ \REF{ex:det:241}.
Content 1: \gsrc Yokombla mï \textbf{minanganiken} lamndu masap. | \gll Yokombla mï \textbf{min=angani-ka-en} lamndu ma=asa-p | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ 3DU=before-let-NMLZ pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `Yokombla killed the third pig.’
Content 2: \gsrc Amiwa mï \textbf{ndanganiken} lamndu masap. | \gll Amiwa mï \textbf{ndï=angani-ka-en} lamndu ma=asa-p | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ 3PL=before-let-NMLZ pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `Amiwa killed the fourth pig.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:det:241}, ndanganiken ‘the one following them’ could refer to any ordinal number fourth or greater (or third or greater, if \isi{plural} marking may be allowed for \isi{dual} referents, \sectref{sec:9.1.2}). Thus, there is no straightforward means of distinguishing \is{ordinal numeral} ordinals in Ulwa beyond first-second-third.
Content 1: \gsrc Amiwa mï \textbf{ndanganiken} lamndu masap. | \gll Amiwa mï \textbf{ndï=angani-ka-en} lamndu ma=asa-p | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ 3PL=before-let-NMLZ pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `Amiwa killed the fourth pig.’
